steps.theyMight: Did you know your vehicle light is broken?
steps.youCanSay: Thank you for letting me know. I'll get it repaired. Can I see the issue?
steps.whatItMeans: You're acknowledging the issue without admitting guilt or getting defensive.
steps.whatHappensNext: They may issue a challan (traffic ticket) or warning. Ask for the written challan.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't say 'No, it's not broken!' without checking. Don't admit to knowing it was broken.

steps.theyMight: This is a serious violation. The fine is ₹1000.
steps.youCanSay: Understood. Can you show me the rule this violates? May I have the receipt and challan number?
steps.whatItMeans: You're being professional and asking for documentation, which protects your rights.
steps.whatHappensNext: They will provide a challan. Make note of the officer's name and vehicle number.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't negotiate the fine on the spot. Don't hand over only cash without a receipt.

steps.theyMight: Just give me ₹500 cash and you can go.
steps.youCanSay: I need a proper receipt and challan. If I can't pay now, what's the proper procedure?
steps.whatItMeans: You're refusing informal payments and insisting on transparency.
steps.whatHappensNext: If they continue pressuring, note their details and report to the traffic police helpline.
steps.avoidSaying: Never pay cash without receipt. Don't be rude—stay calm and firm.

scripts.title: Police Wants to Search Your Home

steps.theyMight: We need to search your home for [reason]. Let us in.
steps.youCanSay: I'd like to see the search warrant first. What is it for?
steps.whatItMeans: You're asserting your right to know the legal reason before allowing entry.
steps.whatHappensNext: They must show you a valid warrant. If they don't have one, you can refuse entry.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't say 'No, leave immediately!' aggressively. Stay calm and respectful.

steps.theyMight: We have the authority. Open the door.
steps.youCanSay: Please show me the warrant. I'll cooperate fully once I see the legal order.
steps.whatItMeans: You're standing firm on your legal rights while appearing cooperative.
steps.whatHappensNext: If they have a warrant, you must allow the search. Be present during it and note what is taken.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't physically block the door. Don't become aggressive or violent.

steps.theyMight: We'll take this item as evidence.
steps.youCanSay: Please provide me a receipt listing all items being taken. I want it in writing.
steps.whatItMeans: You're creating a record of what was seized for your legal protection.
steps.whatHappensNext: They should provide a seizure memo. Keep a copy and note the officer's name and date.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't physically grab items back. Don't refuse to let them take things.

steps.theyMight: We need to ask you some questions. Come to the station.
steps.youCanSay: Am I being arrested or detained? What is this regarding?
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking for clarification about your status—essential for knowing your rights.
steps.whatHappensNext: They must tell you if you're detained. You have the right to know the reason.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't say 'I won't answer anything.' Don't become uncooperative yet.

steps.theyMight: Just come answer a few questions. It won't take long.
steps.youCanSay: Can I call someone to inform them where I'm going? Can I have your name and the station details?
steps.whatItMeans: You're exercising your right to inform family and getting official details.
steps.whatHappensNext: They may or may not allow a call. Make sure to remember their details.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't go without telling anyone where you're going.

steps.theyMight: Just confess and this will be over quickly.
steps.youCanSay: I'd like to speak to a lawyer before answering detailed questions. Can I have a lawyer present?
steps.whatItMeans: You're invoking your right to legal representation, which is your fundamental right.
steps.whatHappensNext: They must allow you to have a lawyer. Don't answer questions without one for serious cases.
steps.avoidSaying: Never confess to something you didn't do. Never sign anything without understanding it.

scripts.title: HR Cuts Your Salary Without Notice

steps.theyMight: Due to performance issues, we're reducing your salary by 20%.
steps.youCanSay: Thank you for informing me. Can I have this in writing? What specific performance issues are you referring to?
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking for written documentation and clarity on the reason.
steps.whatHappensNext: They should provide written notice. If this is the first time, ask for a performance improvement plan.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't accept verbal changes. Always ask for written documentation.

steps.theyMight: We've already decided. The new salary is effective immediately.
steps.youCanSay: I understand, but I'd like written clarification on whether this is temporary or permanent, and if there was proper notice period given.
steps.whatItMeans: You're insisting on proper process and documentation.
steps.whatHappensNext: In India, salary cuts need notice (usually 30 days) and written explanation. Request this formally.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't resign in anger immediately. Get everything in writing first.

steps.theyMight: If you don't agree, you're free to leave.
steps.youCanSay: I'd like to understand the terms. Can we discuss this and can I have a copy of my employment contract and the modification notice in writing?
steps.whatItMeans: You're standing firm on your right to clarity and legal documentation.
steps.whatHappensNext: If you feel this is unfair, you can file a complaint with the Labour Department.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't say 'I quit!' without documenting the issue. This may affect your severance.

steps.theyMight: Your services are no longer required. Your last day is today.
steps.youCanSay: I understand. Can I have the termination letter in writing with the reason and final settlement details?
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking for written documentation of the termination.
steps.whatHappensNext: You have the right to a termination letter. It should mention the reason and final amount due.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't sign anything immediately without reading it carefully.

steps.theyMight: We'll send the termination letter later. For now, hand over your access card and laptop.
steps.youCanSay: I'll handover everything. But can I get a signed acknowledgment that I'm returning these items? I also need a copy of the termination letter today itself.
steps.whatItMeans: You're ensuring documentation of handover and insisting on the termination letter.
steps.whatHappensNext: Get a receipt for all items you're returning. Keep a copy.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't return things without written acknowledgment of handover.

steps.theyMight: We'll calculate your dues and send via bank transfer.
steps.youCanSay: Can I have the calculation breakdown in writing? This should include salary, gratuity, leave encashment, and any other dues.
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking for transparency in the final settlement calculation.
steps.whatHappensNext: Review the calculation. If anything seems wrong, raise a formal objection before accepting payment.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't accept a check without verifying the amount against your calculation.

steps.theyMight: You're incompetent. No one likes working with you.
steps.youCanSay: I don't appreciate that language. If there are specific work concerns, please provide feedback in writing so I can improve.
steps.whatItMeans: You're setting a professional boundary and asking for constructive feedback instead.
steps.whatHappensNext: If the behavior continues, document it with dates and details.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't respond with insults or emotional reactions.

steps.theyMight: I'm considering removing you from the project because of your attitude.
steps.youCanSay: I understand your concerns. Can we discuss this with HR present so there's clarity on expectations?
steps.whatItMeans: You're requesting a formal discussion with HR as a witness.
steps.whatHappensNext: Having HR present creates documentation and protects both parties.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't accept informal threats about your job status.

steps.theyMight: Forget HR. Just accept my feedback or find another job.
steps.youCanSay: I need to document this conversation. I'm filing a formal complaint with HR regarding workplace conduct.
steps.whatItMeans: You're escalating the issue to the official channel.
steps.whatHappensNext: File a formal complaint in writing with HR. Keep copies of all communications.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't threaten back or make this personal.

scripts.title: College Says You Have Low Attendance

steps.theyMight: Your attendance is below 75%. You're at risk of being debarred.
steps.youCanSay: Thank you for the heads-up. Can I see the attendance record? I'd like to understand where the shortfall is.
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking for documentation and clarity on the issue.
steps.whatHappensNext: Review the records carefully. There might be errors or medical leave that wasn't marked.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't ignore the warning. This is serious and can affect your exams.

steps.theyMight: No exceptions. If you miss classes, we must fail you.
steps.youCanSay: I understand the policy. If I have medical or emergency reasons, what's the procedure to get exemptions or make-up classes?
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking about legitimate exceptions within the college's own procedures.
steps.whatHappensNext: Most colleges have procedures for medical leaves. Request the proper documentation.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't argue that the policy is unfair. Ask about procedures within the system.

steps.theyMight: You need to appeal to the Dean. That costs ₹2000 and there's no guarantee.
steps.youCanSay: Can I have the appeal procedure and criteria in writing? What's the timeline for the decision?
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking for transparency and formal procedures.
steps.whatHappensNext: Get everything in writing. Check your college's handbook for appeals policy.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't pay money without understanding what you're paying for.

scripts.title: College Denies Your Exam Recheck Request

steps.theyMight: We've reviewed the papers. The marks are correct. No rechecking.
steps.youCanSay: Can I see the answer sheet and the evaluated copy? I'd like to understand which answers were marked wrong.
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking to view your own answer sheet, which is usually your right.
steps.whatHappensNext: Most colleges allow this. Ask when you can view it and who will be present.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't accept a 'No' without asking why you can't see your own sheet.

steps.theyMight: The examiner's decision is final.
steps.youCanSay: I understand. However, I believe there's a scoring error in Question 5. Can you show me the grading rubric used?
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking for the objective criteria used for marking.
steps.whatHappensNext: If the rubric shows your answer should have been marked differently, you have grounds for recheck.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't claim 'the examiner is biased.' Stick to objective errors.

steps.theyMight: There's an appeal fee of ₹1000. It goes through a committee.
steps.youCanSay: What's the committee composition? How long does it take? Can I have the appeal process in writing?
steps.whatItMeans: You're asking for detailed information before committing money.
steps.whatHappensNext: Appeal through the formal process if you genuinely believe there's an error.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't pay without knowing who will review and how long it takes.

steps.theyMight: Come to our room. It's just some fun tasks for freshers.
steps.youCanSay: Thank you for the invite, but I'd prefer to skip. I'm not comfortable with informal activities.
steps.whatItMeans: You're politely refusing without being rude.
steps.whatHappensNext: If they insist or pressure you, this crosses into ragging territory.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't go. Don't think 'it's just fun.' Trust your instincts.

steps.theyMight: Don't be stuck up. Everyone does this. You have to participate.
steps.youCanSay: I appreciate the welcome, but I'm not interested. Please respect that.
steps.whatItMeans: You're setting a firm boundary.
steps.whatHappensNext: If they continue, this is harassment. Document it with dates and people involved.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't feel pressured to 'fit in' through harmful activities.

steps.theyMight: If you don't participate, you'll be isolated in this college.
steps.youCanSay: I understand, but I need to report this. Can I speak to the Anti-Ragging Committee?
steps.whatItMeans: You're escalating to the official body that handles ragging cases.
steps.whatHappensNext: Every college has an Anti-Ragging Committee. This is a serious offense and will be investigated.
steps.avoidSaying: Don't stay silent thinking it'll pass. Report immediately.
